document.masterDocTitle: New records, taxonomic notes, and the description of a new species of Reduviidae (Hemiptera: Heteroptera) from Ecuador

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: New records, taxonomic notes, and the description of a new species of Reduviidae (Hemiptera: Heteroptera) from Ecuador

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis.
Sinchocoris giupponii
sp. nov.
can be separated from other species of
Sinchocoris
by the following combination of characters: (1) ratio of lengths of visible labial segments II:III:IV as 5:3:1 (other species) or 2:2:1 (
S. giupponii
sp. nov.
); (2) midlongitudinal sulcus of pronotum reduced to a series of punctuations, obsolete anteriorly and posteriorly in other species, while in
S. giupponii
sp. nov.
this sulcus is even more reduced, in which, there is only a very shallow small impression on distal half of fore lobe, a mid oval depression just below level of transverse furrow in hind lobe, followed by a very thin sulcus barely exceeding the basal half of hind lobe; (3) ventral margin of middle femora with (
S. colombiensis
and
S. panamensis
) or without (
S. giupponii
sp. nov.
) papillae; (4) spongy fossa of fore and middle tibiae moderately developed, at least one-quarter the length of fore tibiae in
S. colombiensis
and
S. panamensis
and very small, only 1/12 times the length of fore tibiae in
S. giupponii
sp. nov.
; (5) abdominal tergites without punctuations in
S. colombiensis
and
S. panamensis
and punctuate in
S. giupponii
sp. nov.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 6–9.
Sinchocoris colombiensis Dougherty, 1995
, male holotype UCR_ENT 0 0 124199 (AMNH), 6, dorsal view, 7, labels, 8–9, middle femur, 8, posterior view, 9, ventral view, papillae pointed by arrows.

FIGURES 10–13.
Sinchocoris panamensis Dougherty, 1995
, male holotype, UCR_ENT 0 0 124200 (AMNH), 10, dorsal view, 11, labels, 12–13, middle femur, 12, lateral view, fringe of setae pointed by arrows, 13, ventral view, papillae pointed by arrows.

FIGURES 14–16.
Sinchocoris giupponii
sp. nov.
, male holotype, 14–15, dorsal view, scale bar 2.0 mm, 14, as originally mounted, glued to a card by ventral portion of the body, 15, remounted on a narrow plastic card, glued only by a small portion the body, 16, head and thorax, lateral view, scale bar 1.0 mm.

treatment.paragraph:
Etymology . The new species is named in honor of Dr Alessandro Ponce de Leão Giupponi (Oswaldo Cruz Institute, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil), for his great contribution to the study of Arachnida
.

subSubSection.materialsCitation: Type material . ECUADOR . Male holotype: Coca/Mayo—65 [v. 1965]/Ecuador//L. F. Pena/Col. [ leg .] (CEI- OC)

paragraph.subSubSection:
Comments . The holotype was originally mounted on a card ( Fig. 14 ). In order to study it properly it was necessary to remove the specimen from the mounting card and modify the position of some of its legs. Despite all care taken, the right antenna ( Figs. 14–15 ), right fore leg, left fore tibia and tarsus, right hind leg and the abdomen ( Figs. 16–17 , 23) broke off. These portions will be glued back on the specimen or glued on a card to be pinned together with it. Although the detachment of these portions was not desirable or intentional, they allowed documenting the apex of fore tibia, showing the respective spongy fossa ( Fig. 22 ) and the dorsal view of the abdomen ( Fig. 23 ). .
FIGURES 17–20. Sinchocoris giupponii sp. nov. , male holotype, 17–19, scale bar 1.0 mm, 17, head and thorax, dorsal view, 18–20, right fore leg, 18–19, lateral view, 18, inner surface, 19, outer surface, 20, trochanter and femur, ventral view, scale bar 0.5 mm.
FIGURES 21–24.
Sinchocoris giupponii
sp. nov.
, male holotype, 21, left fore leg, apex of trochanter and femur, ventral view, scale bar 0.5 mm, 22, apex of fore tibia, ventral view, arrows point to spongy fossa, scale bar 0.1 mm, 23–24, abdomen, scale bar 1.0 mm, 23, dorsal view, 24, ventral view.
FIGURES 25–27.
Sinchocoris giupponii
sp. nov.
, male genitalia, 25–26, scale bar 0.1 mm, 25, medial process of pygophore, anterior view, 26, paramere, 27, phallus, lateral view, scale bar 0.2 mm, art , articulatory apparatus, dps , dorsal phallothecal sclerite, en , endosoma, sbp , subapical sclerotized suboval process.
The structures present on the ventral margin of fore femora of all species ( Figs. 20–21 ) and at the basal portion of middle femora of
S. colombiensis
( Fig. 9 ) and
S. panamensis
( Fig. 13 ), considered as denticles by Dougherty (1995) , seem more similar to papillae as described by
Forthman et al . (2016
, Pl. 16D, E) and were considered here as such.
